EDIT 1 ( MAIN PART OF THE REVIEW BELOW ):

Since people actually somehow managed to find this review, I decided to put at least a little bit of an actual review in here. Not a detailed one because I haven't played the game for a long time, but my personal information about the game.

(SIDENOTE: If you want a review that follows a linear flow of explaining information, this isn't the one. I mainly jump around from topic to topic, mostly because this came from the top of my head.)

( Sorry random OCD guy.)


Tribes:Ascend is a great game, but sadly, a lot of players are missing from the game because developers have moved onto SMITE and they abandoned this game a while ago.

They have made some changes to the game though, that has varied since the release of Tribes:Ascend. One thing they did was cut back on the amount of grinding required, which was really nice for F2P players. The game certainly isn't pay-to-win, but it is deterring to see that a playstyle you want isn't available for you. Most of the default stuff are mostly usable, but I do have to point out that the other weapons are just more fun to use. ( And sometimes more effective. )

The gameplay features high-speed combat, which will be very rewarding to those who value skill.
Coordinated roles and classes give the game a nice feel for it's objective based gameplay, and offers multiple different playstyles. Supportive roles, defensive roles, and offensive roles are ALL viable, and they all help you win the game. There's also a in-game voice communication system that slightly helps with immersion ( if you're into that sort of thing. )

There's also a few game modes ( many of which are probably dead. ).

My personal favorite is Capture the Flag, because it requires a variety of roles by the team.
Maybe you want to be the guy who grabs the flag at high speed.
Maybe you want to be the guy who sits on the flag and laughs at the guy who just died because he rammed into you at high speed.
Or maybe, you want to be like a sneaky ninja and blow stuff up. ( People included. )

The amount of skill required in this game is more than any normal FPS. You can't just aim down the sights of your gun and kill a guy in 1 second. You need to actually try to kill him, because 95% of the weapon in this game are not hitscan, which means you WILL have to shoot ahead of a moving target and if you want your projectile to even land CLOSE to him.

Experienced players will 'blue plate' someone. ( Blue plate is when you hit a poor guy directly with a spinfusor. )

Newer players may find it easier to use rapid-firing weapons until they're ready to try out the Spinfusor.

New players will also learn the term 'Shazbot!' ( Which will not be explained here. )

There is progression in this game, but they unlock different playstyles and weapons, rather than directly upgrading your weapons. ( Not counting some of the other things you can upgrade, but let's forget about those for now. )

You don't unlock a grip for your gun to reduce 15% penalty to accuracy, you don't get a scope and whatever, you'll actually want to unlock other classes and weapons. One of the classes has access to a fractal grenade ( the disco grenade ) and another class has invisibility. I'm not going to list every single class, but you get the point.

Weapons play a large part of Tribes as well as the classes. While a technician can put down a turret, some guy on a hill can make it rain explosives on him and clear the objective for a friendly to move in.

Sadly, you won't be able to unlock TotalBiscuit's voice unless you pay real money.


Yes. His voice is in the game.

You can also buy skins and stuff so you look different. Not like you'd show it off to anyone anyways.


You can also get credits or whatever to buy resupply points and call in orbital strikes.
Credits are only for the duration of the match, so feel free to call in the thunder.

As for performance, I've always had a problem on low-end PCs, so this isn't really the game you want to be playing on a low budget, but you shouldn't really have any performance problems if you have a medium to high end rig. There's a few performance.ini's on the internet somewhere if you really wanna play this on a potato. Trust me, I tried, and I at least went fast enough to kill something.


If you've read the original portion of the review, I joke about how no one plays this ( because no one does ) but that doesn't mean I don't want anyone to play it.


If you have slogged through this thing that steam calls a review, give Tribes a try. If you like it, tell your friends. Maybe it'll actually have some people playing it. ( Yeah right. )

The best example of how you shouldn't make a modern old-school FPS.

This game introduced me to the Tribes series, and during beta and the first months after release it has been one of the best FPS I've ever played.
But it was ruined and later abandoned by incompetent (or just greedy, I don't really know) developers who couldn't manage the early and sudden success of the game, and made it a horrible pay to win hitscan fest with no anticheat, adding more and more unbalanced, overpriced and overpowered content instead of fixing the blatant flaws the game had, thus turning away both veterans and new players (who faced a huge paywall or hundreds of hours of grinding just to play the game with adequate equipment).

After a few months, nostalgia led me to try Tribes 2, which is the clearest example of why Ascend failed (classes, loadouts, weapon balance etc), but I eventually stopped playing it because of high latency and very low population.

I quit playing Ascend like 2 years ago, but right now, with all these upcoming/released new arena fps, it came to my mind and I realised that I don't really care about a new Unreal Tournament or all these Quake clones (that I surely will play and enjoy!), I just want a new Tribes game DONE RIGHT:

- no free to play model
- classes, physics, map and weapon designs have to be studied to provide the most balanced and fair gameplay
- content must be limited in order to keep the game balanced

All these features were mostly overlooked by Ascend's developers.

I've been replaying this recently and loving it (I use the non-steam client) so I thought I'd repost this recommendation now that the character limit has gone.
======
So far the best iteration of Tribes since Tribes 2. What's more its free to play so you've got no excuse not to give it a try.

Skiing
For those who don't know the series Tribes offers team based gameplay with one of the best movement mechanics in arena style FPS called skiing.
It combines physics, jetpacks, the environment and the skill of the player to have you rocketing around the map at the speed of sound and makes for some excellent chases in capture the flag type scenarios and great combat that has you estimating trajectories of projectiles and players to produce some of the most epic trickshots you'll see in any game.

Classes
It also has a really nice class system that has subtle class differences which are exaggerated by player role choices in game. The subtlety results in a much more natural role selection basic much more on strategy rather than the I'm playing the heavy-defender class therefore I only defend"

Map Design
One thing that also stands out to me is that I think the map design is beautiful for an arena game. While they do share some common features on the whole each map feels unique and have loads of great little details to bring them to life.

FTP
Finally for those who are nervous about free to plays being pay to win (as I was until recently) Tribes: Ascend feels like its got the right balance of paying giving you enough perks to make it worth it (which is important if you want the game to stay alive) but without being an essential element to play and kick ♥♥♥♥. reviewText:
Did you like Tribes? Did you like Tribes 2? Did you like Tribes: V- hahahahahah, no one likes Tribes: Vengeance. But you might like Tribes: Ascend. The fundamental mechanics(especially after the latest pair of patches) are very much Ye Olde Tribes. You pick an armor weight, you pick a weapons-and-gear loadout, you spawn, you use your jetpack, you ski, you eat a spinfusor to the face like thirty times before you remember that Tribes isn't like other FPS games.

But then you get your first Air Mail or Blue Plate Special(mid-air kill), and suddenly you're having fun. Because suddenly you GET it. You get into five-minute duels with others, you grab the flag at 300kph(or stop a capper going at 300kph) and you GRIN, and suddenly it's 2am and you have to make an executive decision whether to go to work with five hours of sleep or play Tribes for another three hours and calling in sick.

The only thing holding back Tribes: Ascend is really a few balance issues(Beowulf tanks are currently a bit pitiful and Shrikes could use a mild nerf) and some map design issues(on some maps, generators and base assets are very vestigial indeed), but you should still play the game, because on the good maps, you're really going to be having a LOT of fun once you get the hang of it.

Plus, you know, the damn thing's FREE. Kind of hard to beat that price, especially since they stripped out the grinding aspects that usually come with F2P games.

reviewText:
It's good again guys.

Quick Pro-Con Lost

PRO:
-The movement. I mean god damn, does it put games like Titianfall and the latest cawadoody entry to shame. The entire game is played with an exo-suit that makes you feel like you've got an ACME rocket-powered skatboard welded to your feet at all times. With the hilly structure of nearly all of the maps, it's like the worlds most dangerous skate park - but with guns and Capture the Flag.

-The weapons. Don't expect too many traditional pew pews in Tribes. This game is fought primarily with high-velocity explosive frisbees. Spinfusors are the name of the game, and learning to use one is easy, but eyeballing the trajectory, distance, and speed of your enemy as they go screaming across the map and scoring a hit is a ♥♥♥♥♥ to master. Weapon variety is enough to keep you happy, and each one has it's own little purpose.

-The classes. Old Tribes players will disticntly remember nine in total, but with recent updates it's been shaved down to three; light, medium, and heavy. Don't worry, this is probably my favorite new feature, as it allows more creativity in creating them. Classes are simple, light means go fast, heavy means big armor, and medium is a balance between the two. With the new additions, you can really carve out your niche in the match. Want to have some heavy offensive ordinance AND be able to deploy a turret now? You can. Want to carry a crossbow and a Jackal at the same time? No more class restriction on that. Chaingun AND Heavy spinfusor AND Fractal Grenade? Yep, that too. The sky's the limit.

-The graphics. Not on par with a triple-A 2016 release but still really pretty if you crank everything up to max, and can still be set low enough to play on a toaster. The gameplay is the focus here.

-It's free. What more could you want?

SO-SO
-Cannot be played through Steam, so your favorite dank meme name is a no-go.
-Serves can get a bit underpopulated, but that's not bad in my opinion becaue you see a few famailiar faces from time to time.


CON:
-Learning curve is a bit frusturating. 20 hours in and I'm still getting my behind kicked.
-May be dead as a doornail in a year or two.
-I can't think of anythig else.

reviewText:
This is a fast past FPS game that requires teamwork, the game sets it self apart from other FPS games out there. You will ski around at speed outmaneuvering each other.
Shooting requires a whole other way of aiming than any other shooter you probably know. You need quick reaction, intuition and a steady aim while you your self is on the move.
This game is easy to play, but freakishly hard to master. Early on you will be steamrolled all over the place by the skilled players (even on lowranked server due to high-ranked players re-rolling to play on low ranked servers). It will be frustrating, but with a bit of practice you will learn how to move to prevent being trashed all the time. Movement is really, really, really, important.
Btw, Did I mention how important movement is to survive in the game?
Standing still will turn you into mincemeat in no time (camping = death).
In the normal random game you can do whatever you like, more or less, but if you join a “PickUpGroup” (play a pug) game, you will be put in the setting of competitive gaming. It is recommended and a ton of fun.
They will teach you how to play properly. Just tell them that you are new and need to learn ;)

Try it out. It is worth it.

The downside……
Hi-Rez got greedy. When their DotA clone turned profitable, they removed all support for Tribes. The game is now dead in the eye of the maker and only the players are left to fence for them self.
And because of this, the game is in a decline and will die out sooner or later, depending on how stubborn the game-community is.

reviewText:
Tribes Ascend has made a comeback with a new patch which removes the classes and once again allows you to play as you want.

Most if not all of the fillter content has been removed, which means the classes have been removed... Sorta. Instead of there being the 9 classes from before the devs have gone back to the original system that uses the three armour types as the classes, much like the older games released by Dynamix and Irrational and Hi-Rez (the devs) improved on it in just about every way.

Each armour type has their own set of weapons, grenades and packs. From the generic light, medium and heavy variants  of some weapons to weapons that only that armour type can use, such as a rocket launcher for the heavy or the throwing knives for the light.

Calldowns have been removed and the item that was used as the calldown laser has been reused as the targeting laser or range finder from Tribes 2 and the deployable inventory station has been changed from a calldown to a pack-style deployable much like the older games.

The vehicle play remains pretty much un-altered but credits have been removed so they're are free, although credits are still used as part of your score in game.

In addition to the old armour system returning you can also carry up to 3 weapons as light and medium or 4 as heavy, weapons are also selected with your number keys instead of a single cycle weapon binding.

Although there are some bugs and problems with the game as a result of these major changes such as every weapon not being unlocked for every slot and loadout for each class and some of the server options no longer working because the functions related to them are no longer there.

Weapons are no longer upgradeable so when you buy a weapon their stats don't go up or down through using it and the perk system has also been removed aswell.

In short i'd say Tribes Ascend now lives up to the previous titles in the series and is well worth the download. Hopfully Hi-Rez puts this much effort into the next Tribes-esque game they release.

This game, although no longer being updated by Hi-Rez, is one of the best FPS titles on the market. It has high quality graphics, 9 different classes, and a free to play system that is less Pay-2-Win than most.

Pros:

-The game looks great
-Tons of different weapons and items to unlock
-No Storyline so maximum replayability
-A community much better than COD or those types of games
-Gameplay that is often based on skill

Cons:

-The system may not be Pay-2-Win, but paying for the Game of the Year gives noobs an advantage over other noobs because certain unlockables are straight upgrades.
-The classes are NOT balanced. Certain classes are ridiculously strong while others are borderline underpowered. That being said, a pro can make any of these classes work but they would do better using a good class
-Although generally based on skill, some of the more overpowered classes simply rely on pressing a button to win
-Weapons are not balanced either, with stock weapons that aren't even used.
-Unlocks cost an exceptional amount. Certain unlocks that are required to play a subclass (Chaser on Pathfinder for example) require you to earn over 40 games worth of exp.

That being said, this game is still a great FPS, easily kicking COD and those cookie-cutters right off the map.

It's a little less entertaining now, to say the least.

HISTORY:
Tribes is an old franchise that goes all the way to 1999 with Starsiege: Tribes. It differentiated itself from other futuristic shooters by having wide open maps, vehicles, class system (similar to what Battlefield 1942 did 3 years later) and jetpacks. Then later on, Tribes 2 came and further expanded on the idea, adding skiing (which is one of the few cases of a bug becoming a core feature of a franchise). It was well received and a couple of years later, Tribes: Vengeance came out and it was the first attempt to try streamlining the formula, however it wasn't well received by fans. And so, Tribes IP languished year after year, at one time developer called GarageGames (who made Fallen Empire: Legions, heavily (by heavily I mean almost completely copied) inspired by Tribes) bought the IP with the intent of remaking Tribes 1 for their InstantAction platform (which might be defunct now), til Hi-Rez bought the rights and set on to develop Tribes: Ascend.

-Vehicles. It isn't like Call of Duty or some other shooter genre where all you do is run and run and grab flag and die. THe vehicles are great, granting you either supreme mobility or heavy firepower. I personally love the Air vehicle(forgot what it's called).
-The physics. This game uses real life physics, and gives you velocity and all that stuff.
-Skiing. This game also introduces no friction mode, which allows you to slide on the the surface. It is pretty hard to master, but with lots of practice, you'll get used to it. With the skills with jetpack and skiing, you'll become the best in the game!
Cons-
-No more updates. This game was released quite a while ago, and have been updated frequently for a while, until March 2013, when the last update we ever saw came out.
No other cons :D

I bought the closed beta in October 2011, and having never played any of the original tribes I was hooked. The game was a whole different ballgame than what I've played in the last 15 years. Having come from military shooters, with the exception of some co-op and TF2, I was looking forward to the projectile game as that's all I cared for in TF2 and I never got big in to quake either back in the day.

When T:A went F2P I -- like most closed beta -- had high hopes it would be 'the next big thing' but boy we were wrong. As time went on and the game expanded you realized the developers had no idea about anything at all. Map Designers had no logic in their design, no maps made sense as to where you may find assets / repair guns / vehicle pads / inventory stations. Some maps do not even offer vehicles (not talking ones with them disabled). While it's not terribly hard to play the maps a few times and learn them you'll find yourself irritated so much with the fact there's no standardized design for maps. Suiciding will become your friend.

After you make peace with terrible map design (to be fair 20-33% aren't too bad, but all lack consistancy you'll find in every major fps) you'll come to realize that the weapons are super inbalanced. The game started off with pretty much projectiles, save the inf (no one used it) and soldier AR. As time moved on everyone got machine guns. This was a big blow to the game in term of longetivity and probably is the main reason it's died. Not only were none of the maps designed with such weapons in everyones hands (no cover to hide from the literal 1-5k bullet spam per 20 seconds) but using a [timed] health regen system on top makes regending impossible unless you camp your base (which is why all pub games are defense).

Anyone who has time logged knows autos are super easy to use, because they have no recoil, no spread. The only one which is implemented in a great way is the pathfinder lar -- because it's limited to 3 shot burst , and with a from-beta-possibly-alpha bug of dry firing you can bank on the person missing a few shots from it not actually firing.

So on top of horrible map design, and imbalanced/spam weapons not compatable with map terrain or the health system you'll find a few other things that are a bit messed up like the snipers. You'll come to find out about this game there's a few things: Hi-Rez thinks the 2% of people who pug (or compete" if you want to call it that) are the only people who play here. if you've ever seen a 'competitive' tribes game you'll see 2 things: endless auto spam

A Paladin’s Review: Tribes: Ascend: Out of the Blue Update. High Speed Fun and Spinfusors for the Win.Genre: Sci-Fi First/Third Person Shooter, Multiplayer Only High Speed Armor Based.
Developed & Published by: Hi-Rez Studios
Platform: Windows only.
DRM: Free Hi-Rez Player Account Required. Steam is optional.
Business Model: Free to Play System. Optional purchases for cosmetic skins, different voices or a weapons pack that unlocks all weapons, perks, items and loadouts immediately.
Played over 100 hours and bought some gold. Most of my playtime is in the non-Steam client. Read this review in its entirety with screenshots and the OST from Bandcamp on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Game Overview
Tribes: Ascend is a multiplayer-only online arena high-speed first person shooter. It’s an everlasting factional warfare between the Blood Eagles and Diamond Swords set in the distant future. These tribes are battling it out for ultimate supremacy in a futuristic Sci-Fi universe where the fighting seems unlikely to stop anytime soon. In-game, this simply affects the color of your armor, the announcer’s voice and where you spawn. Three different armor bases form the basis of what a player can and can’t do at any one time. There are a wide variety of different weapons ranging from explosive projectile weapons, hitscan assault weapons to sniper rifles and more. There are five distinct game modes and more than 40 maps combined spanning these modes. These maps are huge, allowing for high speed build up and action on a giant battleground. Each map is designed with its mode in mind and only share the general aesthetics. There is an official rule set for each mode but you can also set up your own server with custom rules. T:A sets itself apart from other first person shooters with high speed skiing, jet pack action and projectile preference over hitscan weapons. It’s free-to-play which means that T:A has a decent variety of skins and voice packs to customize your look as well. Is it worth checking out? Well, let’s talk about the shooting elements next.

Gameplay Musing
With the Out of The Blue Patch, Hi-Rez has clearly shown that it has learned from the mistakes of the past. The huge amount of grinding is gone, the weapon play feels more balanced than it ever has in the past and Tribes is fun to play again. Despite its quirks and imperfections, Tribes still has something to offer after three years. It’s hard to deny the rush you get when you’re skiing at 300 km/h across the map while dodging all sorts of projectiles thrown your way. The increased flexibility with loadouts makes for a much more interesting play/counterplay setup if the rest of your team is on the ball. I’m not 100% sold on the current weapon or armor balance right now. It’s definitely better than it used to be but some of them, like the bolt launchers, feel superfluous or heavies are a little too good. However, it’s no longer a hitscan nightmare fest that it used to be. Where paid players had a clear advantage over free players. I’ll be curious to see how patches over the months and possibly years go. So far, they seem to be keeping the game going at a regular, if slow, pace.

Development Cycle
Hi-Rez returned in December to give T:A a much needed overhaul in balance and several new maps for players. But that will probably be the exception to the norm. Since then, there’s been smaller bug fix patches, a new map here and there and minor balance changes to address community complaints. Tribes: Ascend seems to be a passion project for Hi-Rez and as such I would temper one’s expectation of regular content. Unfortunately, the Out of the Blue update did not create a substantially larger player base. There was a big jump in players when they announced the patch, but it has since returned to the normal small levels it had before the patch. Even so, the game is playable now without the major issues that used to plague it. I’d say you’ll get about 5-8 public servers going on any particular day. So, there’s always something to do. For now, it seems like Hi-Rez plans on supporting the game for the foreseeable future with small updates to keep the game going.

Final Thoughts
Out of the Blue shows how much Hi-Rez studios has grown since its screwup with Tribes: Ascend. Many of the balance problems are fixed, the large amount of grinding is gone, the business model feels a lot more fair and there’s more content to enjoy. Capture the Flag is clearly the focal point of T:A and its still really fun to play. This is the best state the game has ever been in despite its flaws. The community is still pretty decent too. However, said community is small and may not grow anytime soon unfortunately. There are some aspects of balance that may need to be adjusted as time goes on and I would like to see more content released. It’s also got a pretty difficult learning curve compared to most shooters that can be daunting for new players wanting to experience T:A. While I’ve never gotten particularly great at it, I always try to and its got a challenge that I still find compelling. Its a game whose mechanics, speed and shooting still stand up even after three years of gaming. I definitely recommend checking out Tribes: Ascend especially after this patch that came out of the blue.
